choices: between 25 and 28 years of age.
between 11 and 16 years of age.
between 8 and 10 years of age.
between 18 and 23 years of age.
front.question: The onset of menstruation usually occurs in females who are:

cards.back: between 11 and 16 years of age.

choices: menstrual periods become less frequent.
she can no longer produce an ovum.
she usually requires hormone therapy.
she is capable of becoming pregnant.
front.question: When a female has reached menarche:

cards.back: she is capable of becoming pregnant.

choices: The EMT should try to determine if rape occurred.
Rape causes more physical than emotional harm.
Only a licensed physician can make a diagnosis of rape.
Rape is a legal term, not a medical diagnosis.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding rape is correct?
front.source: See Assessment and Management of Specific Conditions

cards.back: Rape is a legal term, not a medical diagnosis.

choices: limited to a brief survey for life-threatening injuries.
performed in the presence of at least two police officers.
as detailed as possible so all injuries can be documented.
deferred until the patient can be evaluated by a physician.
front.question: The physical examination of a sexual assault victim should be:
front.source: See Assessment and Management of Specific Conditions

cards.back: limited to a brief survey for life-threatening injuries.

choices: only use quotation marks when recording any statements made by witnesses.
keep the report concise and record only what the patient stated in her own words.
translate the patient’s words or statements using proper medical terminology.
record your opinion only if you have reasonable proof to justify the statement.
front.question: When documenting a call in which a female was sexually assaulted, you should:
front.source: See Assessment and Management of Specific Conditions

cards.back: keep the report concise and record only what the patient stated in her own words.

choices: become so emotionally distraught that they contemplate suicide.
experience abdominal cramping, which may be misinterpreted.
lose up to 500 mL of blood within the first 24 hours.
have a false positive home pregnancy test result.
front.question: It is common for young females who experience their first menstrual period to:

cards.back: experience abdominal cramping, which may be misinterpreted.

choices: has formed a general impression of the patient.
ascertains if the patient was ever pregnant.
has obtained a complete set of vital signs.
has gathered patient history information.
front.question: When a woman presents with abdominal pain or other vague symptoms, the EMT is often unable to determine the nature of the problem until he or she:

cards.back: has gathered patient history information.

choices: allow law enforcement to take her statement before you begin treatment.
place any bloodstained clothing or other articles in separate paper bags.
advise her that she will not be allowed to shower or change her clothes.
ask the patient for a concise, detailed report of what happened to her.
front.question: When caring for a female patient who has been sexually assaulted, you should:
front.source: See Assessment and Management of Specific Conditions

cards.back: place any bloodstained clothing or other articles in separate paper bags.

choices: uterus.
cervical os.
vagina.
fallopian tube.
front.question: Each ovary produces an ovum in alternating months and releases it into the:

cards.back: fallopian tube.

choices: she cannot become pregnant because of fluctuating hormone levels.
her risk of developing pelvic inflammatory disease lowers significantly.
she usually experiences abdominal cramping without vaginal bleeding.
her menstrual periods may become irregular and vary in severity.
front.question: As a woman approaches menopause:

cards.back: her menstrual periods may become irregular and vary in severity.

choices: keep assessment and treatment to a minimum.
ask questions related to her gynecologic history.
determine the underlying cause of her problem.
maintain her ABCs and transport without delay.
front.question: When caring for a woman who is experiencing a gynecologic emergency, the EMT’s main focus should be to:

cards.back: maintain her ABCs and transport without delay.

choices: the patient knew her attacker, but is afraid to say.
the traumatic experience has created a mental block.
the patient was given a drug prior to the incident.
an underlying head injury is causing her amnesia.
front.question: EMTs receive a call for a possible sexual assault. The patient is a young female who is conscious and alert and has no apparent injuries. She states, “I can’t remember anything, but I know I was raped.” The EMTs should suspect that:
front.source: See Assessment and Management of Specific Conditions

cards.back: the patient was given a drug prior to the incident.

choices: PID most commonly affects women who have had an ectopic pregnancy in the past.
PID can scar the fallopian tubes, which increases the risk of an ectopic pregnancy.
The most severe cases of PID occur in women who are not sexually active.
The most common presenting symptom of PID is generalized upper abdominal pain.
front.question: Which of the following statements regarding pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is correct?

cards.back: PID can scar the fallopian tubes, which increases the risk of an ectopic pregnancy.

choices: uterus.
urinary bladder.
ovaries.
fallopian tubes.
front.question: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) typically does NOT affect the:

cards.back: urinary bladder.

choices: often presents with acute pain.
is typically not as severe.
can be controlled in the field.
may be relatively painless.
front.question: In contrast to bleeding caused by external trauma to the vagina, bleeding caused by conditions such as polyps or cancer:

cards.back: may be relatively painless.

choices: supplemental oxygen and keeping the patient supine.
carefully removing any foreign bodies from the vagina.
refraining from placing any dressings into the vagina.
treating external lacerations with sterile compresses.
front.question: General treatment for a woman with vaginal bleeding and shock following sexual assault includes all of the following, EXCEPT:

cards.back: carefully removing any foreign bodies from the vagina.

given the option of being treated by a female EMT.
encouraged to take a shower and change her clothes.
asked to provide a brief description of the perpetrator.
front.question: Whenever possible, a female sexual assault victim should be:

cards.back: given the option of being treated by a female EMT.

choices: thins and begins to separate.
becomes engorged with blood.
diverts blood flow to the vagina.
sheds and is expelled externally.
front.question: In anticipation of receiving a fertilized ovum, the lining of the uterine wall:

cards.back: becomes engorged with blood.

choices: Ovarian cysts
Chlamydia
Ectopic pregnancy
Genital herpes
front.question: Which of the following conditions would MOST likely lead to pelvic inflammatory disease if left untreated?

cards.back: Chlamydia

ovarian cysts and gonorrhea.
ovarian abscess and ectopic pregnancy.

front.question: Potentially life-threatening consequences of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) include:

cards.back: ovarian abscess and ectopic pregnancy.
